elements.content: A novel Zn-MOF-based photochromic complex with tunable photophysical behavior has been developed. The control of luminescent emission and color can be achieved in a single compound by utilizing suitable molecular self-assembly of luminophore and photochromic component.

elements.clean_text: A novel Zn-MOF-based photochromic complex with tunable photophysical behavior has been developed. The control of luminescent emission and color can be achieved in a single compound by utilizing suitable molecular self-assembly of luminophore and photochromic component.

elements.content: Luminescent materials based on the metal–organic framework (MOF) have attracted significant attention for their wide applications in detection, sensing, biological labeling, and light-emitting diodes. Since MOF complexes are well-defined crystalline solids constructed by metal ions and organic bridging ligands through metal–ligand coordination bonds, this provides an opportunity to fabricate their photoactive characters via manipulating building units that aggregate into extended macromolecular networks. Tuning the luminescent properties of photoactive complexes by external stimuli is particularly attractive for the development of ultra-high-density optical memories and super-high-resolution fluorescence imaging. In this context, modification of the luminescence color in response to light stimuli is one interesting strategy to fulfill the purpose. Photochromic compounds are a kind of functional material that can respond to external light stimulus with reversible color change. Their intrinsically intriguing properties have already led to real applications in optical information storage, light control, and optical switches. For many photochromic–luminescent molecular systems, the photochromic process is usually coupled with a reversible luminescence change. Energy transfer takes place between the photoactive components, which causes the whole emission quenching due to good spectral overlap between the emission bands of the luminescent components and the broad UV absorption bands of the colored photochromic units. However, photochromic–luminescent molecules act in this way only showing light-shade conversion, which excludes the possibility to tune the luminescence color. Considering partial spectral overlap of the absorption–emission bands as one strategy to achieve the goal of color modification, we have embarked on a program aimed at modulating the luminescence emission color by the photochromic reaction of viologen charge transfer complexes. Herein, we report a luminescence–photochromism molecular switch based on a host–guest zinc metal–organic framework with methyl viologen dication (MV2+) as template and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate (BTEC) as connected ligand [MV]­[Zn3(BTEC)2(H2O)2]·H2O 1. The objectives of the construction of this photosensitive dyad molecular system are (a) the luminescent emission band of BTEC ranges from 350 to 600 nm, which is partly overlapped with the UV absorption band of MV+ radical (500–800 nm). It may readily build a molecular switch with two-color luminescence emissions; (b) the polynuclear cluster constructed units build a stable photoresponding MOF system with the advantages of light resistance and durability; (c) the compact arrangement of [Zn3(BTEC)2(H2O)2] anionic host framework and MV2+ guest cations results in closer interaction distances that create electron transfer channels for the photoactive components. Upon light irradiation, compound 1 shows a photochromic nature with BTEC anion and MV2+cation as the electron donor (D) and acceptor (A), respectively. More interestingly, the luminescence color of its crystalline sample also can be reversibly switched from pale beige to dark green by light stimuli, displaying photocontrolled luminescence behavior.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent materials based on the metal-organic framework (MOF) have attracted significant attention for their wide applications in detection, sensing, biological labeling, and light-emitting diodes. Since MOF complexes are well-defined crystalline solids constructed by metal ions and organic bridging ligands through metal-ligand coordination bonds, this provides an opportunity to fabricate their photoactive characters via manipulating building units that aggregate into extended macromolecular networks. Tuning the luminescent properties of photoactive complexes by external stimuli is particularly attractive for the development of ultra-high-density optical memories and super-high-resolution fluorescence imaging. In this context, modification of the luminescence color in response to light stimuli is one interesting strategy to fulfill the purpose. Photochromic compounds are a kind of functional material that can respond to external light stimulus with reversible color change. Their intrinsically intriguing properties have already led to real applications in optical information storage, light control, and optical switches. For many photochromic-luminescent molecular systems, the photochromic process is usually coupled with a reversible luminescence change. Energy transfer takes place between the photoactive components, which causes the whole emission quenching due to good spectral overlap between the emission bands of the luminescent components and the broad UV absorption bands of the colored photochromic units. However, photochromic-luminescent molecules act in this way only showing light-shade conversion, which excludes the possibility to tune the luminescence color. Considering partial spectral overlap of the absorption-emission bands as one strategy to achieve the goal of color modification, we have embarked on a program aimed at modulating the luminescence emission color by the photochromic reaction of viologen charge transfer complexes. Herein, we report a luminescence-photochromism molecular switch based on a host-guest zinc metal-organic framework with methyl viologen dication (MV2+) as template and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate (BTEC) as connected ligand [MV][Zn3(BTEC)2(H2O)2]⋅H2O 1. The objectives of the construction of this photosensitive dyad molecular system are (a) the luminescent emission band of BTEC ranges from 350 to 600 nm, which is partly overlapped with the UV absorption band of MV+ radical (500-800 nm). It may readily build a molecular switch with two-color luminescence emissions; (b) the polynuclear cluster constructed units build a stable photoresponding MOF system with the advantages of light resistance and durability; (c) the compact arrangement of [Zn3(BTEC)2(H2O)2] anionic host framework and MV2+ guest cations results in closer interaction distances that create electron transfer channels for the photoactive components. Upon light irradiation, compound 1 shows a photochromic nature with BTEC anion and MV2+cation as the electron donor (D) and acceptor (A), respectively. More interestingly, the luminescence color of its crystalline sample also can be reversibly switched from pale beige to dark green by light stimuli, displaying photocontrolled luminescence behavior.

elements.content: The title dyad material was prepared via an in situ solvothermal reaction of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, viologen diacetic acid dichloride, and BTEC. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data indicate that 1 has high phase purity, and it retains framework stability and crystallinity up to 140 °C (Figure S3). Single crystal analysis reveals that the viologen diacetic acid dichloride molecule is hydrolyzed to produce an MV2+cation as the template agent among the solvothermal process. Its structure contains a three-dimensional porous network with four different types of zinc­(II) centers as connected nodes. Three zinc ions (Zn1, Zn2, and Zn4) are tetrahedrally coordinated with four oxygen atoms of BTEC ligands in a unidentate mode (a). The last one (Zn3) accepts a square-pyramidal geometry with three oxygen atoms of BTEC ligand and two oxygen atoms of water molecules. The linkage of the tetrahedral and pyramidal units by the BTEC ligand yields a 3D framework with three types of cavities (b). MV2+cations occupy the largest pores in a direction parallel to the channels. The compact arrangements make the distances between the oxygen atoms of the carboxyl groups and the N atoms of viologen rings vary from 3.244(5) to 3.546(4) Å. Such distance values are favorable for an intermolecular electron transfer between the carboxylate group of BTEC and the pyridinium moiety of viologen (Figure S1a). Furthermore, the arrangement of the pyridine ring of guest viologen template and the benzene rings of the host frameworks accepts a typical offset stacked conformation with the centroid–centroid separation of 3.594(6) Å (Figure S1b). These weak interactions construct a favorable geometry for the photoinduced electron transfer reaction. Solid-state UV–vis spectrum of compound 1 shows high absorption bands centered at 300 nm, which relate to π–π* transitions of the conjugated aromatic rings. A shoulder peak distinctly observed around 450 nm can be ascribed to the formation of a charge transfer (CT) complex through π–π stacking interactions between the photoactive MV2+cations and the carboxylate ligands. Upon light irradiation (150 W xenon lamp), the brown crystals of 1 change their color to dark blue (). Meanwhile, a new UV–vis absorption band at 610 nm is observed to be increasing with extended irradiation time. The good matching of PXRD and IR data (Figures S3a and S4) before and after irradiation indicates that there is no structural change among the photochromic processes. ESR measurements support the fact that the process is accompanied by the generation of radicals (g = 2.0085) (Figure S5), which is similar to previous reports for viologen species. The mechanism of radical formation for this donor–acceptor photochromic complex has been well documented. The electron deficient viologen unit is the electron acceptor, while the electron-rich benzene carboxylate group acts as the electron donor under photoirradiation. For the reverse photochromic reaction, bleaching occurs when the sample is heated at 120 °C in the air.
elements.clean_text: The title dyad material was prepared via an in situ solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, viologen diacetic acid dichloride, and BTEC. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data indicate that 1 has high phase purity, and it retains framework stability and crystallinity up to 140 °C (Figure S3). Single crystal analysis reveals that the viologen diacetic acid dichloride molecule is hydrolyzed to produce an MV2+cation as the template agent among the solvothermal process. Its structure contains a three-dimensional porous network with four different types of zinc(II) centers as connected nodes. Three zinc ions (Zn1, Zn2, and Zn4) are tetrahedrally coordinated with four oxygen atoms of BTEC ligands in a unidentate mode (a). The last one (Zn3) accepts a square-pyramidal geometry with three oxygen atoms of BTEC ligand and two oxygen atoms of water molecules. The linkage of the tetrahedral and pyramidal units by the BTEC ligand yields a 3D framework with three types of cavities (b). MV2+cations occupy the largest pores in a direction parallel to the channels. The compact arrangements make the distances between the oxygen atoms of the carboxyl groups and the N atoms of viologen rings vary from 3.244(5) to 3.546(4) Å. Such distance values are favorable for an intermolecular electron transfer between the carboxylate group of BTEC and the pyridinium moiety of viologen (Figure S1a). Solid-state UV-vis spectrum of compound 1 shows high absorption bands centered at 300 nm, which relate to π-π* transitions of the conjugated aromatic rings. elements.content: Structure of compound 1: (a) the asymmetric unit; (b) extended 3D framework showing the MV2+dications embedded in the channels viewed along the 1̅1̅0 direction.

elements.content: (a) UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectral changes of 1 upon light irradiation. (b) Solid-state emission spectrum of 1 at room temperature (the yellow–green trace, λex = 420 nm). Insets: photographs of the sample before and after irradiation.

elements.content: At room temperature, compound 1 emits strong pale beige light (534 nm) upon excitation at 420 nm with a PL quantum yield of 5.40% (). Close packing arrangement of donor (carboxylate group) and acceptor (methyl viologen dication) units enable the functional system to give rise to distinguished emission energies that originate from localized frontier molecular orbitals (the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) at the donor, and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) at the acceptor). Another intense photoluminescence emission at ca. 476 nm is assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) within the zinc carboxylate framework. Interestingly, the photochromic reaction of 1 is coupled with its photoluminescence emissions. In the photogenerated species, either electron transfer or energy transfer can quench the excited state of the luminophore. As shown in , the partly overlapped bands of photoluminescence emission and the UV absorption provide a chance for energy transfer from the luminophore to methyl viologen radicals, which finally achieve the purpose of light emission modulation. Upon exposure to continuous photoirradiation, the photoluminescence emission decreases dramatically in contrast to the enhancement of UV–vis absorbance in the same area. The intensity at 476 and 534 nm decreases to 45% and 33%, respectively, of the starting value after 3 min irradiation with a PL quantum yield of 2.11% (Figure S6). Kinetic calculation results indicate that the increase in UV–vis absorption is proportional to the decrease of luminescence intensity (). Its solid-state light reversion followed at 610 nm and luminescence quenching occurred at 534 nm exhibit first-order kinetics and gives similar rate constants with k obs = 2.5 × 10–2 s–1 and 2.7 × 10–2 s–1 for photochromic and luminescence modulation process, respectively. As a consequence, compound 1 gives dark green light after photoirradiation. As the thermal regeneration of the original form of the photochrome would suppress the quenching process, it could switch the emission of the luminophore back on. Thus, the dual-color luminescent switching is reversible accompanied by the photochromic process. Relative intensities of the pale beige and dark-green emissions can be controlled by the photoirradiation time. As far as we know, this is the first example of a single component dual-light-emitting switching device based on a coordination molecular system that involves a photoinduced electron transfer process.

Close packing arrangement of donor (carboxylate group) and acceptor (methyl viologen dication) units enable the functional system to give rise to distinguished emission energies that originate from localized frontier molecular orbitals (the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) at the donor, and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) at the acceptor). Another intense photoluminescence emission at ca. 476 nm is assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) within the zinc carboxylate framework. Interestingly, the photochromic reaction of 1 is coupled with its photoluminescence emissions. In the photogenerated species, either electron transfer or energy transfer can quench the excited state of the luminophore. As shown in , the partly overlapped bands of photoluminescence emission and the UV absorption provide a chance for energy transfer from the luminophore to methyl viologen radicals, which finally achieve the purpose of light emission modulation. Upon exposure to continuous photoirradiation, the photoluminescence emission decreases dramatically in contrast to the enhancement of UV-vis absorbance in the same area. The intensity at 476 and 534 nm decreases to 45% and 33%, respectively, of the starting value after 3 min irradiation with a PL quantum yield of 2.11% (Figure S6). Kinetic calculation results indicate that the increase in UV-vis absorption is proportional to the decrease of luminescence intensity (). As the thermal regeneration of the original form of the photochrome would suppress the quenching process, it could switch the emission of the luminophore back on. Relative intensities of the pale beige and dark-green emissions can be controlled by the photoirradiation time. As far as we know, this is the first example of a single component dual-light-emitting switching device based on a coordination molecular system that involves a photoinduced electron transfer process.

elements.content: Solid-state kinetic traces of 1: (a) and (c) photo coloration based on UV absorption at 610 nm; (b) and (d) luminescence quenching based on the emission intensity of 534 nm.

elements.content: In summary, a novel Zn-MOF-based photochromic complex with tunable photophysical behavior has been developed. Partly overlapped bands of photoluminescence and UV spectra in 1 result its selective luminescence quenching. The control of luminescent emission and color can be achieved in a single compound by utilizing suitable molecular self-assembly of luminophore and photochromic component. Stable structure of Zn-MOF provides a durable D–A framework with photostimulus luminescence patterning, reversible luminescence switching, and nondestructive readout of the luminescence signal. The luminescent–photochromic building-block strategy is valuable for the design of new smart systems with luminescent color tuning properties. This class of materials may find their potential applications in data storage, signal processing, and sensing for their ability to modulate a fluorescence output under the influence of optical stimulation.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a novel Zn-MOF-based photochromic complex with tunable photophysical behavior has been developed. Partly overlapped bands of photoluminescence and UV spectra in 1 result its selective luminescence quenching. The control of luminescent emission and color can be achieved in a single compound by utilizing suitable molecular self-assembly of luminophore and photochromic component. Stable structure of Zn-MOF provides a durable D-A framework with photostimulus luminescence patterning, reversible luminescence switching, and nondestructive readout of the luminescence signal. The luminescent-photochromic building-block strategy is valuable for the design of new smart systems with luminescent color tuning properties. This class of materials may find their potential applications in data storage, signal processing, and sensing for their ability to modulate a fluorescence output under the influence of optical stimulation.

metadata.title:
Zn-MOF-Based Photoswitchable Dyad That Exhibits Photocontrolled
Luminescence
